footnotes: 'Make a brazen serpent, and set it up for a sign: whosoever being struck shall look on it, shall live.'
Jesus applies this directly to Himself: 'As Moses lifted up the serpent in the wilderness, so must the Son of man be lifted up' (John 3:14).
The bronze serpent is Christ on the Cross: look and live. Faith involves looking to the crucified Savior for healing from the serpent's poison (sin).
'When the serpent of brass was set up, whosoever... beheld it, was healed.'
The serpent symbolizes sin; the bronze (judged, rendered harmless) serpent represents Christ 'made sin for us' (2 Cor 5:21) yet sinless.
Healing comes through beholding—faith in the crucified Christ. Not works but looking.
'A star shall rise out of Jacob, and a sceptre shall spring up from Israel'—Balaam's prophecy of the Messiah.
The Magi saw 'his star in the east' (Matt 2:2), fulfilling this oracle. Christ is the star of Jacob and rightful king of Israel.
